<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 625, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 195, 537, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 235, 527, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 262, 561, 295]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 308, 537, 324]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 343, 613, 378]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - \chi^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 384, 537, 418]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{\nu\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 429, 537, 463]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 470, 628, 490]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 502, 598, 522]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 533, 527, 560]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 572, 531, 590]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 606, 598, 625]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 638, 628, 658]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 670, 517, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 718, 558, 735]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 751, 581, 769]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 780, 536, 814]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 675, 91]]<|/det|>
A fishing rod AB, made from the rod in **(b)**, is shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 100, 781, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 297, 591, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
End A of the rod rests on the ground and a string is attached to the other end B. A support stick exerts a force perpendicular to the rod at point C. The weight of the rod acts at point D.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 376, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
The tension \(T\) in the string is in a direction perpendicular to the rod. The rod is in equilibrium and inclined at an angle of \(56^{\circ}\) to the vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 422, 885, 441]]<|/det|>
The forces and the distances along the rod of points A, B, C and D are shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 181, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 454, 843, 473]]<|/det|>
Show that the component of the weight that is perpendicular to the rod is \(4.3 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 574, 180, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

By taking moments about end A of the rod, calculate the tension \(T\).

<form>T = .................................................... N [3]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 782, 91]]<|/det|>
A small block is lifted vertically upwards by a toy aircraft, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 228, 532, 247]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
As the block is moving upwards, the string breaks at time \(t = 0\). The block initially continues moving upwards and then falls and hits the ground at time \(t = 0.90 \text{s}\). The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the block is shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 317, 789, 510]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 536, 534, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

Air resistance is negligible.

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 630, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A ball falls vertically downwards towards a horizontal floor and then rebounds along its original path, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 205, 794, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 297, 536, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 920, 362]]<|/det|>
The ball reaches the floor with speed \(3.8 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The ball is then in contact with the floor for a time of \(0.081 \text{s}\) before leaving it with speed \(1.7 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The mass of the ball is \(0.062 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 287, 181, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 287, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
A school experiment is performed on a metal wire to determine the Young modulus of the metal. A force is applied to one end of the wire which is fixed at the other end. The variation of the force \(F\) with extension \(x\) of the wire is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 348, 712, 523]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 537, 532, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 570, 566, 588]]<|/det|>
The maximum force applied to the wire is \(F_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 600, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
The gradient of the graph line in Fig. 4.1 is \(G\). The wire has initial length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 647, 913, 665]]<|/det|>
Determine an expression, in terms of \(A\), \(G\) and \(L\), for the Young modulus \(E\) of the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 834, 920, 853]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student repeats the experiment in **(b)**(i) using a new wire that has twice the diameter of the first wire. The initial length of the wire and the metal of the wire are unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.1, draw the graph line representing the new wire for the force increasing from \(F = 0\) to \(F = F_1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
